ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CSP  –  country strategy and program 
  DGF  –  Development Grant Facility, World Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  MTS  –  medium-term strategy 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  RM  –  resident mission 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by Grant Curtis, NGO Center of the  
Regional and Sustainable Development Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The 1998 policy of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on cooperation between ADB and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), directs ADB to expand its cooperation with NGOs. Such 
cooperation aims to strengthen the effectiveness, sustainability, and quality of the development 
services ADB offers. The policy also calls for the integration of NGO experience, knowledge, and 
expertise into the institution’s operations so that ADB-supported activities will more effectively 
address the issues and priorities reflected in ADB’s development agenda.   
 
2.  ADB’s  Long  Term  Strategic  Framework  indicates  that  ADB  will  seek  to  expand  its 
partnership agenda by developing ways of working closely with NGOs and the private sector. The 
framework gives priority to the development of modalities for working with NGOs and civil society, 
and commits ADB to developing mechanisms for direct support to local and regional governments 
(including cities and municipalities) as well as to civil society organizations. ADB’s Medium-Term 
Strategy (MTS) calls for the development of new modalities for working with NGOs, in addition to 
those undertaken under the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and including the development of 
funding (and control) mechanisms that will allow NGOs direct access to ADB funds. The MTS 
indicates that ADB will develop methods that will allow NGOs to implement a wider range of ADB 
projects  and  programs,  particularly  targeted  poverty  interventions,  with  the  review  and 
development of new assistance modalities to be undertaken in 2003. 
 
3.  From  June  through  November  2002,  ADB’s  NGO  Center  conducted  a  series  of 
14 participatory workshops throughout the Asia and Pacific region through TA 6021.1 The TA's 
workshops involved about 500 representatives from ADB’s major stakeholders:  governments, 
NGOs, the private sector, and ADB resident mission and headquarters staff. The consultation 
process culminated in a 1 week “writeshop” during which selected regional participants jointly 
prepared the first draft of “ADB-Government-NGO Cooperation: A Framework for Action 2003-
2005”  (the  NGO  Cooperation  Framework).  By  providing  an  action  plan  for  enhanced  ADB-
government-NGO  cooperation,  the  NGO  Cooperation  Framework  also  fulfills  a  major 
recommendation of the Presidential Committee and Task Force on ADB-NGO Cooperation.   
 
4.  A key recommendation of the NGO Cooperation Framework is for ADB to establish a 
separate  funding  modality  that  will  provide  NGOs  with  direct  access  to  ADB  funding;  this 
recommendation  echoes  the  MTS  (para.  2).  Such  a  mechanism  will  demonstrate  ADB’s 
commitment to cooperation with NGOs through financial support to innovative NGO development 
activities, including  
 
(i)  new approaches to poverty reduction and sustainable development;  
(ii)  pilot projects with potential for replication or upscaling;  
(iii)  introduction of new technologies or methodologies;  
(iv)  improved methods of monitoring or auditing the delivery of public services;  
(v)  improved  or  enhanced  transparency,  good  governance,  and  capacity  building 
activities; and  
(vi)  better  means  of  including  marginalized  or  vulnerable  groups  in  ADB  project 
activities.  
 
This regional technical assistance (TA) lays the foundation for a separate ADB funding modality for 
NGO activities.2

5.  The World Bank’s Development Grant Facility (DGF) integrates overall strategy, allocations, 
and management of the World Bank’s grant-making activities funded from its administrative budget 
under a single umbrella mechanism. The DGF has firmly established grant-making as an integral 
part of the World Bank’s overall development strategy as well as an important complement to its 
lending and advisory services. In 2003, the DGF budget is $157.0 million, covering 48 grant 
programs,  including  the  Small  Grants  Program  (which  supports  civic  engagement  for  the 
empowerment of marginalized and vulnerable groups), the Post Conflict Fund, and the Institutional 
Development  Fund.  The  Inter-American Development Bank similarly has established an NGO 
grant funding mechanism.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
6.  As outlined by the September 2001 Report of the Task Force on Institutional Arrangements 
for Cooperation with Nongovernment Organizations,3 ADB-NGO cooperation is realized through 
two parallel streams:   
 
(i)  strategic/thematic institutional cooperation through which ADB engages NGOs in 
continuing consultation and dialogue on cross-cutting issues; and  
(ii)  operational cooperation at the country and project levels, including NGO provision of 
advice or as a source of information for project identification and design as well as 
roles of consultants, implementing agencies, monitoring agencies, and evaluators.  
 
7.  Enhanced engagement with NGOs can 
 
(i)  promote public consensus and local ownership; 
(ii)  give  voice  to  the  concerns  of  primary  and  secondary  stakeholders, 
particularly the disadvantaged such as poor women and ethnic minorities; 
(iii)  strengthen and leverage the impact of development programs; 
(iv)  bring innovative ideas and solutions to development challenges; 
(v)  provide professional expertise and increased capacity; and  
(vi)  improve  public  transparency  and  accountability,  thus  enhancing  the 
environment for good governance. 
 
8.  ADB’s  1998  policy  on  cooperation  between  ADB  and  NGOs  explicitly  recognizes  the 
importance  of  capacity  building  and  institutional  development  support  to  developing  member 
countries (DMCs) as part of the overall effort to improve the human and social capital needed to 
support effective poverty reduction. In this context, ADB recognizes the critical role of NGOs in 
development and the importance of capacity building and institutional development support to 
NGOs to strengthen this role.   
 
9.  ADB  has  made  great  strides  in  deepening  and  broadening  its  collaboration  with 
developmental  NGOs.  At  the  same  time,  cooperation  activities  have  not  been  implemented 
consistently throughout the institution, or across ADB’s operations. Although NGOs are understood 
to be important development actors, the quality of ADB-NGO interaction remains suboptimal, due 
in  part  to  lack  of  institutional  capabilities  for  and  knowledge  of  how  to  cultivate  effective 
development partnerships. Much remains to be done before ADB will be able to benefit fully from 
the skills and strengths that NGOs can bring to ADB operations.

10.  Issues central to effective ADB-NGO cooperation have been identified in a number of ADB 
and  other  reports,  as  well  as  through  various  studies.4  Additional  critical  factors  in  ADB’s 
relationship with NGOs emerged from the series of ADB-government-NGO workshops held under 
TA 6021.  The issues or factors can be clustered around five key needs:   
 
(i)  to strengthen stakeholder involvement in ADB-supported activities,  
(ii)  to enhance transparency and interaction through access to information,  
(iii)  to strengthen capacities to support cooperation among stakeholders,  
(iv)  to build NGO capacity and provide institutional, and  
(v)  to strengthen Government-NGO cooperation. 
 
In addition to these critical factors, a related issue is how enhanced tripartite cooperation among 
ADB-governments-NGOs can be mainstreamed into ADB’s products and services. The NGO 
Cooperation  Framework  proposes  specific  activities  to  be  implemented  during  2003–2005  to 
increase effective development cooperation.   
 
11.   A dynamic and more grounded ADB-government-NGO relationship has been constrained 
by ADB’s lack of a mechanism that provides NGOs with direct access to ADB funding for capacity 
development, poverty reduction, or other mutually beneficial development activities.  Although the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction provides a funding mechanism for NGO-implemented activities, 
it requires that such activities must have a direct connection to existing or planned ADB loan 
projects. This limitation has prevented ADB from supporting innovative NGO activities that might 
complement ADB’s poverty reduction efforts at the country or regional levels. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.   The TA’s overall goal is the enhanced development of long-term strategic partnerships with 
NGOs and governments to achieve poverty reduction in the Asia and Pacific region. Increased 
NGO  involvement  in  ADB’s  support  to  government-led  development  efforts  will  increase  the 
effectiveness, sustainability, and quality of ADB’s services to its DMCs. The specific purpose is to 
provide funding to a limited number of NGOs in Group A and B DMCs to undertake innovative 
poverty reduction or other activities in key ADB sectors as identified through approved country 
strategy and program (CSP) documents.5  The TA framework is presented in Appendix 1.

5   Eligible  Group  A  countries  include  Afghanistan,  Bhutan,  Cambodia,  Kiribati,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Lao  People's 
Democratic Republic, Maldives, Mongolia, Nepal, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tajikistan, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu.  
Eligible Group B countries include Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, Cook Islands, Indonesia, Marshall Islands, Federated 
States of Micronesia, Nauru, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, People’s Republic of China, Sri Lanka, Tonga, 
Turkmenistan, and Viet Nam.  India (as a Group B country) is excluded from the TA in that the United Kingdom’s 
Department for International Development (DFID) has established a separate poverty reduction fund for India.  
Myanmar also is excluded from this TA.

4    
13.   Expected TA deliverables include (i) the identification and approval of up to $50,000 in 
NGO-implemented poverty reduction or national development or related activities, such as NGO 
capacity  building  in  each  participating  DMC;  (ii)  outputs  of  such  activities;  and  (iii)  full 
documentation of methodologies used, results, and lessons learned. Experience with implementing 
the TA, including the identification and approval of innovative NGO-implemented activities and TA 
implementation arrangements, will directly contribute to ADB’s consideration of a separate funding 
window  for  NGOs  in  support  of  key  poverty  reduction  activities  (as  per  the  MTS  and  the 
recommendations of the NGO Cooperation Framework).  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The TA will, among other things, (i) provide funding to a limited number of NGO-designed 
and implemented project activities that are of strategic relevance to ADB’s operations in eligible 
DMCs; (ii) support NGO engagement in strategic and constructive poverty-related discussions with 
ADB and governments; (iii) build the capacity of local NGOs to help them work with ADB and 
governments in the context of ADB’s operations in the Asia and Pacific region; and (iv) use the 
experience gained during the TA to design and establish a larger, long-term assistance window to 
support NGO poverty reduction activities. 
 
15.   Major assumptions include the willingness of NGOs in eligible DMCs to access funding for 
innovative  poverty  reduction  activities  provided  through  the  TA,  and  concurrence  from  DMC 
governments.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.    The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis 
through the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund. As it is not possible to specify the detailed costs 
of prospective NGO funding requests, Appendix 2 provides only a broad cost estimate table. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB’s NGO Center will have overall responsibility for TA implementation, including the 
development of guidelines (for use  by RMs), a  template for NGO project proposals, reporting 
formats, etc.  
 
18.  The TA will provide small grants to NGOs through RMs (or through regional departments, in 
countries without RMs) for activities directly related to poverty reduction and enhanced ADB-
government-NGO cooperation. Experienced NGOs in eligible DMCs may submit proposals to a 
maximum ceiling of $50,000 per eligible country, with no single project to be larger than $20,000.  
Eligibility criteria for NGOs are provided in Appendix 3. 
 
19.  RMs will solicit funding proposals from experienced NGOs. Such proposals, which must 
relate  to  key  ADB  sectors  of  operation  as  determined  by  CSPs,  should  focus  on  discrete, 
innovative, or demonstration approaches to poverty reduction and/or NGO capacity development.  
Criteria for grant funding will include (i) relevance to CSPs and national poverty reduction efforts, 
including feasibility of upscaling as part of ADB operations; (ii) contribution to stronger and more 
productive linkages between ADB, Governments, and NGOs; (iii) contribution to NGO capacity to 
productively and proactively work with ADB and governments; (iv) contribution to improved NGO 
institutional capacity to respond to the needs of the poor; and (v) partner contributions, including 
cash or in-kind contributions by NGOs involved in individual project activities.  RMs, in consultation 
with the NGO Center, will establish country-specific criteria for the partnership grants, in line with 
the criteria outlined above.

5 
 
20.  Project submissions will fall into three broad categories:  (i) pilot or other demonstration 
projects; (ii) capacity-building activities such as NGO skills exchange and the establishment of 
NGO  information  centers  focusing  on  collaborative  work  with  ADB  and  other  major  funding 
agencies; and (iii) support to local NGOs in providing direct feedback to ADB on issues of high 
mutual  concern,  such  as  ADB  sectoral  strategies.    RMs  will  screen  and  prioritize  project 
submissions via a local committee with government, civil society, and donor representatives (where 
appropriate).  RMs also will arrange the translation into English of those projects recommended for 
approval.   
 
21.  The NGO and Civil Society Committee, chaired by the NGO Center, will review projects 
recommended  by  RMs  on  a  periodic  (e.g.,  quarterly  or  rolling)  basis,  with  project  approval 
delegated to the Committee. Funding for approved projects will be disbursed in 2003. No project 
funds will be disbursed without first securing an approval or “no objection” letter for the regional 
technical assistance from the Government concerned. 
 
22.  Approved projects will be completed within a 9–12 month time frame, with full completion of 
the  TA  by  no  later  than  the  end  of  2004.  Each  approved  project  must  have  a  designated 
headquarters-based “patron” who will be responsible for identifying lessons learned, including the 
possibility of upscaling or otherwise incorporating project results into ADB operational activities.  
Patrons will be selected in discussion between the concerned RM, regional department, and the 
NGO Center.   
 
23.  The RM, the regional department patron, and/or NGO Center staff will monitor the projects, 
and  NGOs  receiving  grant  funding  will  be  required  to  prepare  project  completion  reports.  
Generally, lessons learned from approved projects and their implementation will be extracted from 
brief project progress reports (prepared by funding recipients), supplemented by brief field visit(s) 
scheduled in conjunction with other in-country project monitoring activities (including by RM or 
other  headquarters  staff).  The  NGO  Center  will  prepare  an  overall  summary  of  activities 
undertaken through the TA and lessons learned, particularly with respect to the establishment and 
operation of a larger ADB direct funding mechanism or facility for NGO activities that complement 
ADB’s country-based poverty reduction efforts.   
 
24.  During, but separate from, the TA, ADB’s Strategy and Policy Department and the NGO 
Center will jointly undertake a complementary study on funding mechanisms and institutional 
structures for enhanced ADB-NGO cooperation. The TA will fund a regional workshop to discuss 
lessons emerging from the TA implementation as well as resource implications and proposed 
implementation arrangements for a larger ADB direct funding mechanism for NGOs. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis from the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund for NGO Partnerships for Poverty 
Reduction, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR NONGOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS 
 
1.  To  be  eligible  for  funding,  a  nongovernment  organization  (NGO)  or  civil  society 
organization must 
 
(i)  operate in a developing member country (DMC) of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB);  
  (ii)  be a not-for-profit organization; 
  (iii)  be legally registered in an ADB member country;  
  (iv)  have operated for at least 3 years and have a demonstrated track record in  
                        implementing small innovative project activities; 
  (v)  have a management or advisory board; 
  (vi)  have a minimum of two paid staff;  
  (vi)  maintain a proper accounting and financial system; and 
(vii)  be committed to the principles of gender equality in terms of its own staffing, 
involvement of women in decision-making roles, and targeting of women as 
beneficiaries. 
 
2.  Projects will be selected on a competitive basis within eligible countries (with some 
competition among countries and resident missions, due to limited overall funding).  NGOs will 
be expected to  contribute to overall project costs, either on a financial or in-kind (e.g., staff 
salaries) basis.  The project grants normally will not fund NGO administrative or other overhead 
costs, or construction or capital purchase costs.  Nor will project grants fund research programs, 
formal academic training programs, ongoing institutional core support (such as equipment 
unrelated to the activity), scholarships, fellowships, study programs, individuals applying on their 
own behalf, or applications from nonlegal entities.   
 
3.  Recommendations for funding will be made on the basis of the following criteria: 
 
(i)  Eligibility.  The organization must be legally registered in an ADB member 
country. 
 
(ii)  Organizational Strength.   What is the track record of the organization?  What 
are the qualifications and/or experience of key personnel?  Is the organization 
well-known in the DMC?  What is the gender balance within the organization?  Is 
there sufficient institutional capacity to deliver?  Does the organization maintain 
sound  internal  controls,  and  accounting  and  financial  systems?    Does  the 
organization have the capacity to liquidate funds? 
 
(iii)  Financial Viability.   Is the proposed budget feasible and/or realistic?  Is the 
organization able to make a financial or in-kind contribution to the project (e.g., 
staff salaries)?   
 
(iv)  Poverty  Reduction.     Does  the  project  have  direct  or  indirect  operational 
relevance  for  ADB,  based  on  country  strategy  and  program  documentation 
and/or national development/poverty reduction plans? 
 
(v)  Objectives.   How important, innovative, and/or strategic are the objectives of 
the organization’s proposed project?  Are those objectives feasible, given the 
small amount of funding?

10      Appendix 3     
 
(vi)  Methodology.   Is there a clear implementation plan?  Is the timetable realistic?  
Are those objectives feasible?  How creative/innovative and participatory are the 
activities included in the project?  Is the proposal logically presented?  Are there 
any  unsupported  assumptions?    Are  participatory  approaches  to  be  used, 
including involvement of women? 
 
(vii)  Impact.   What are the expected results of the project?  What is the anticipated 
effect on target beneficiaries (i.e., change in legislation, change in institutional 
behavior including use of participatory approaches, change in policy, increased 
public awareness, capacity to access resources, etc.)?  How are project-related 
products  to  be  used  or  distributed?    Are  there  expected  linkages  to  other 
initiatives?  Are the expected results measurable?   
 
(viii)  Relevance  for  ADB.      Does  the  project  have  potential  for  scaling-up  or 
replication in an ADB-financed project?  Could the organization be involved in 
other  ADB-financed  projects?    Has  an  ADB  headquarters  “patron”  been 
identified? 
 
(ix)  Sustainability.   Does the proposal include plans for continuation of activities 
beyond the life of the grant?  Are additional funding sources required?  Have they 
been secured? 
 
(x)     Evaluation.   What are the plans for monitoring, evaluating, and documenting the 
initiative?  Does the project budget include adequate provision for monitoring and 
evaluation? 
 
4.  In  addition  to  equitable  regional  distribution  across  eligible  DMCs,  the  technical 
assistance (TA) will strive for equitable subject focus distribution within the context of national 
development  and  poverty  reduction  plans  and/or  ADB  country  strategy  and  program 
documentation.
